text: That Shannon Sharpe bit aged like outside milk in summer üò≠üò≠üò≠

author: @na_k
text: As a Grizzlies' fan, I appreciated your video. Ja should've been held accountable for his actions in breaking team/league rules. But far too many, including black folks, wanted him thrown away. Those people didn't have the same energy for current players who have actually harmed women, and were accused of (allegedly) having relationships with minors.

author: @franekkkkk
text: I‚Äôve seen plenty of people calling on him to be put in jail. Idiotic. Half of them probably have a gun themselves. Many a whole arsenal.

author: @habib670
text: I have been WAITING for someone to make this type of argument. Allen Iverson went through the same media scrutiny for his appearance and most people look back saying "the NBA did AI dirty, it wasn't that serious" and yet are so quick to put the hammer down on JA for...playing with a gun.

replies.author: @floydtheeebarber
replies.text: Fantastic point. Glad you brought this up.

replies.author: @habib670
replies.text:
‚Äã@F the way AI presented himself at the peak of his public scrutiny was seen and talked about in exactly the same way as JA is being discussed, in that, AI was glorifying "gang culture" by way of his presentation. 

The only difference between AI and JA is the NBA found a way to make AI's looks palatable (to white audiences) and therefore profitable.

replies.author: @TheCrogun
replies.text: The Malice in The Palace was also around this time. The NBA was scrambling to rebuild their image since the media was saying the NBA was "full of thugs". They focused on AI as an example but they were sending a message to all the players.

replies.author: @habib670
replies.text: @TheCrogun which is what they're doing now. even Stephen A. is saying the NBA is sending a message to other players by suspending JA indefinitely.

author: @mirithilrose54
text: As someone who's from a country where the police don't even carry guns, unless there's a very specific reason, I just want to say... that family Christmas picture is now burned in my brain. I mean wtf??? They're just sitting there wholsomely smiling while armed to the teeth. It's probably one of the most psycho things I've ever seen.

replies.author: @swillz1416
replies.text: How is it psycho, I don't see anything wrong with it. Their using good safety unlike ja, there's nothing wrong with the picture compared to what ja wick is doing which is psycho.

replies.author: @swillz1416

replies.author: @Nightswarmer
replies.text: @ikke2757  The fact that the number one cause of death of children in the US right now is gun violence and accidents should say a lot, but the US, and gun-fanatics of the US especially, are notorious for not giving a single fuck about children, so I guess that doesn't matter, anyway..

author: @ojiugo
text: Damn, why is it like you say what I'm thinking all the time? I remember watching the videos of him with his gun and in the club and my reaction being, I don't get it. He's acting like a young person with a lot of money, what's the problem?  Awesome video breaking down the BS around this issue.

author: @dentlashink
text:
Thank you! My biggest issue with sports media, esp. in TN, was the lack of smoke for a certain Gov. Bill Lee who made it possible to just... get a gun and open carry with no qualifications. Who is tripling down on making guns accessible to increasingly younger buyers after a mass shooting in the city where he conducts business...

I get being annoyed and disappointed at Ja. I'm a fan of the Memphis Grizzlies, and it's been exhausting defending him the first time. But I'm even more exhausted with people making another black celebrity a conduit of rage that needs to be directed at the institutional level. Being mad at symptoms, but not the root causes, is the American way though ü§∑üèø‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

replies.author: @dentlashink
replies.text: And before anyone brings up the first incident being in Denver... allow me to point to another state with an open carry status quo...

replies.author: @olurinatti
replies.text: Exactly!

author: @Open-Fuse
text: All the points on the anti-blackness and patriarchy are spot on in a general sense. Definitely can‚Äôt defend Morant specifically though, as other commenters mentioned he has been in numerous other altercations outside the two main gun incidents. Even threatened to shoot a hater on Twitter saying ‚Äúits free to see how hollows feel‚Äù. NBA had to do something eventually. But I agree with everything you mentioned about the anti-blackness in this entire narrative though, it has been nasty

replies.author: @Open-Fuse
replies.text: Further, I just think the NBA was right in how they handled the situation, but the discourse itself was anti-black. I don‚Äôt see the rule and suspension as the NBA policing the image of a black man. The players don‚Äôt have to hide their personalities in the league, its welcomed. They let miles bridges make (pretty explicit) trap music, have all his teammates feature on it,  the league didn‚Äôt care. As soon as people started getting hurt he was gone, I think they‚Äôre fair.

replies.author: @Mabasei
replies.text: @Open-Fuse but ja hasn‚Äôt hurt anyone‚Ä¶

replies.author: @trumpetking11
replies.text: @Mabasei He allegedly punched a minor at his residence and also went in his house to grab his gun to show said minor it wasn‚Äôt a game. I‚Äôm not saying Ja would‚Äôve used the gun, but him going inside to retrieve is a veiled threat at least.

replies.author: @ojiugo
replies.text: The only reason any of his behavior is being scrutinized is because he's in the NBA and has a high profile.  There are tons people who do the exact same things and act in the exact same way, who are not in the NBA, and most of us just understand that they're just being young and impulsive.  Trash talking is a thing.  Being a dick is a thing.

author: @ombra711
text: Neh, dude doesn't stop at flashing a gun, dude really be trying to live that life lowkey. He's pulled it on people and scared the shit out of a rival team, who is keeping mum on details because they're scared of the backlash. Morant is a problem he's young and dumb, and his moms is not helping.

author: @bowerydoll
text: As usual, sis, you nailed it SOLID and so much more. Am I delusional for wishing that some of the vocal, critical elder basketball players would take this kid under their wing to mentor and support him as a community instead of crossing their arms and castigating him all over the media?? I'm in my 50's and he's a kid to me. Our brains don't fully develop until about age 25 and he's almost there. Impulse control and reasoning don't always easily come to us when we're young. He clearly needs help. Somebody needs to do some kind of intervention before this kid becomes an ancestor way too damn young.

author: @edewor
text: üëèüèæüëèüèæüëèüèæüëèüèæüëèüèæ for making me reconsider my take on the Ja Morant situation.

author: @LiamborninDC
text:
This video is omitting the other incidents that involve Ja Morant. 
He attacked and threatened a teenager he was playing against at a gym. 
There was an incident at a shoe store when his mother called him and said one of the employees was being rude to her, so he came there with his friends to harass and threaten the employees. If memory serves, there was an altercation with one of the employees in the parking lot. 
Another incident happened after an NBA game, when the opposing team was leaving on a bus and a laser scope was being pointed through the window from a car that belonged to Ja Morant, though it is very likely it was a member of his entourage.   
Then he posted a video from the club flashing a gun right after reports of these incidents had come out that resulted in the first suspension, now this other gun flashing video and second suspension. So it isn't just two videos of flashing guns that has him in trouble.

replies.author: @mrbush3418
replies.text: All of this was hear say . None of this was proven .

replies.author: @olurinatti
replies.text: Beloved, I explicitly said if you want a deep dive on Ja Morant to go to ESPN. I said why he was suspended and he was suspended involving the incidents with the gun on IG live, the BULK of the commentary about him online has been about IG live, that's the exact commentary I was responding to and explaining why I have a problem with the anti-blackness involved in the criticism and why we should acknowledge how patriarchy contributes to how men like Ja Morant act out. This video is intentionally themed to be a casual rumination of thoughts about the Ja Morant controversy as its appeared to me, not an expose on him.

replies.author: @Solo-DoLowx504
replies.text: @olurinatti so just ignore the context in which everyone had a problem with Ja? You depict the situation as him just rapping along with a gun, but the context was that he was pointing at the camera in response to the stories of him assaulting someone came out. An assault, if truly happened he got away with for being a rich basketball player.

replies.author: @fakename1656
replies.text: ‚Äã@olurinatti it's clear to me your point on the optics of how this was framed by many online because he is black is üíØ true. But it's disingenuous to ignore the whole context because of some loud mouths online. Those people are dumb but there is a larger pattern of reckless behavior that led to him being suspended. The nba has ton of racist policies to protect its image clearly. But continuing to do stupid things at some points needs accountability.  He was only suspended for 8 games because the league wanted to make money by having him play in the playoffs. He dodged a real punishment but still didn't learn from it. To me that is stupid, the source of which is many lime you pointed out but stupid none the less

replies.author: @elias560
replies.text: @Solo-DoLowx504 how about stop being soft?

replies.author: @kimpacheco8466
replies.text:
Post Hoc rationals.
Were these prior (not proven) actions the reason he was suspended? Or are you trying to unjustly rationalise your position by introducing (at this point) gossip? 
Even if everything you claim is üíØ true, the NBA would have also been aware of this and nonetheless they still signed him. They clearly had no problem with his past behaviour and his suspension was specifically about carelessly showing his legally owned gun.

replies.author: @jaydonrichardson3880
replies.text: ‚Å†@kimpacheco8466 I swear people love talking with no idea of the context, it was a build up of accusations this year the second gun event was the final straw if you followed the nba you‚Äôd understand he was wilding

replies.author: @fakename1656
replies.text: @kimpacheco8466 all this happened this year and after he signed that max 200 million contract extension

replies.author: @kimpacheco8466
@kimpacheco8466
replies.text:
@fakename1656 
What was the point Olurinati was trying to make?

replies.author: @fakename1656
replies.text: @kimpacheco8466 I conceded to the points she made that the policies are racist and dumb f*cks online are tards. But not including those other situations that occurred which did also include guns also frames it as only 2 legak events. The police in the first video could not charge because the complaint was made from the video after, the pacers incident was only ever investigated by the league which led to some of his entourage being banned from games. The fight and gun threats on the teen were investigated by cops but they decided not to charge after a flimsy investigation and there is an actual ongoing civil suit.

replies.author: @jaydonrichardson3880
replies.text: @kimpacheco8466 alleged criminal acts but the context is key everyone knows if you can still play ball unless it‚Äôs confirmed you‚Äôll be fine in the league. But Ja morant was wilding all year and while I agree with the videos message, to ignore the build up of events is disingenuous the media came down hard on the second event gun video as a result. I believe that when discussing these topics the full situation needs to be looked at in the clips used of Sharpe there literally discussing the other accusations. When applying theory‚Äôs and frameworks context is needed and for this situation I think a key chunk in why there‚Äôs so much outrage was missed and while there‚Äôs racist clowns the majority was based on why he‚Äôs acting like a dumbass but the sections on patriarchy make perfect sense.

replies.author: @Solo-DoLowx504
replies.text: @kimpacheco8466 Yes, I can believe whole heartedly that happened lol. Ja Morant is on the track to be one of the biggest draws in the NBA rn. If no charges were filed the NBA has no reason too reprimand him on that front. You are surprised about a mega-star that‚Äôs part of a billion dollar industry wouldn‚Äôt get charged for a shitty thing they did? I didn‚Äôt say it was right but it definitely makes sense.

replies.author: @AlkisGD
replies.text: 6:29 - As a Greek who's never been to your country, the people in the picture are terrifying. Wrong Turn meets Stepford Wives or some such dystopian horror üò¨

replies.author: @LiamborninDC
replies.text: @kimpacheco8466 These are not incidents of "gossip" at all, these incidents were reported in the Washington Post with thorough vetting by the journalist. He was signed well before these incidents happened, these things happened in the last year or so. If anything the NBA is using the gun posts as a cover up reason to downplay these other incidents because he is a rising star in the league. They need and want him for the future of their brand.

replies.author: @LiamborninDC
replies.text: @olurinatti I agree with the points you are making in general but it is a valid criticism that you didn't even mention those other incidents. The NBA is actually protecting Ja Morant by making the focus be about those IG posts rather than the "expose" done by the Washington Post.

replies.author: @kimpacheco8466
@kimpacheco8466
replies.text:
@Solo-DoLowx504 
When you added ‚Äú‚Ä¶I didn‚Äôt say it was right‚Ä¶‚Äù that‚Äôs entirely the point she was focusing on in this video. The parts of the process that seems illogical (because it is) and relying on cultural biases to fill in the gaps of logic.

replies.author: @kimpacheco8466
replies.text:
@LiamborninDC 
Yes he was accused and is filing a counter suit but the point of this video is not if he is guilty or not but the system itself. 
If his guilt or innocence, neither has been confirmed, is your main focus then I strongly advise you to set that aside and rewatch her video. 
As a society we have been conditioned to hyper focus on guilt or innocence of individuals but not why we are being manipulated to do this in the first place. Who benefits from our conditioning and more insidious, who do we most likely presume guilt to?

replies.author: @LiamborninDC
replies.text:
@kimpacheco8466 Oh no, I agree with the overall point of the video. I don't even think he should have been suspended for the 2nd gun flashing video, that is nonsense and the only reason they are doing a suspension is because his team isn't even playing anymore. It is just posturing by them.
My point here is that I want Olay to succeed within this space, to continue to make content and be a voice. That said she has to be held to a standard of "journalistic integrity". When speaking about a person accused of misdeeds, all the incidents should be acknowledged and not just the lesser cherry picked ones. Because then there can be the argument of bias. Not just for this video but moving forward that people can say she doesn't give the full story/context and so should not be taken seriously.

replies.author: @kimpacheco8466
replies.text:
@LiamborninDC 
You are correct, we must keep our sister on point. 
When I viewed this she did say her focus was how ultimately,the system fails us and in particular young men of colour and thus the particulars of this situation were not as important to break down. Maybe she should have said the allegations are still being hashed out in court even now and as a result our opinions about his legal problems are not necessarily germane to the overall problem. 
Ja‚Äôs story is no different than most troubled young men who find themselves in the spotlight no different than when Mike Tyson was at the top of his game.

replies.author: @sophiophile
replies.text:
I live in Canada where we have much more strict gun laws. But, given the fact that his gun is perfectly legal, he did nothing menacing, and many Americans have guns for the purpose of safety (especially as public figures)- I don't see what was wrong with what happened?

You would probably be surprised (or maybe not) by some of the content creators on the left who are gun owners.  It's obviously not something that they advertise regularly, but I can think of 4-5 hosts of channels that I see you comment on regularly that have mentioned once or twice in passing that they have guns.

text:
Super well presented argument. I have to admit when this first appeared on my radar my knee-jerk reaction was to point fingers at Mr. Morant. I appreciate you clarifying the real issues here. 
This is coming from a 50 year old white man from Canada - so the issues at play are all too familiar to me (Canada has had direct access to American media and TV since the 80s - unlike most other countries) yet those issues are still somewhat at arms length. Thanks a bunch for the insight.

author: @MaryJohanna
text:
Very interesting indeed. I think it's pretty basic, he had a contract the man said no negative social media with guns and whatnot, he challenged it and for now he's out. There are thousands undiscovered of equally talented young men out there waiting for their shot. 
Young man had a chance and blew it. I get that the rule is dumb, especially comparing it to all the white folks family pictures with AR 15's. But it was for the job. You're a lawyer, I am sure there are times that you may be expected to dress conservative and maybe not every employer would agree with your youtube presence, so you either take it or leave it. You were also right, the man is still a 23 year old kid and his decision making or impulse control is not completely developed. I wish him well and hope he'll come around.

author: @proudstrangelingstudios5345
text: To Van‚Äôs point, if Ja had a gun enthusiast, YouTube channel I would be on his side, because then that really does become a second amendment, issue! My problem is that Jay is acting like a driller when he‚Äôs a ball player and I‚Äôm only talking about the message that he sending to the kids respectability politics be  damned. As a matter of fact, if Ja was talking, gun ownership, safety, etc. for black folks, then he should be applauded but that ain‚Äôt the case. I‚Äôm not mad about how white people look at us I‚Äôm mad that Ja knows what that imagery is and what it convey‚Äôs our young ‚Ä¶ I would argue that if we have the responsibility to give Ja some grace ‚Ä¶ and not go too harshly on what it looks like‚Ä¶ then he should have some responsibility to the young people that watch him every day drill culture is crazy and it‚Äôs getting out of hand and all though guns in crime we‚Äôre here long before hip-hop music and will be here long after drill music that culture and that imagery is exacerbating a lot of the issues in the hood.  And I do understand that it is a byproduct of patriarchy and capitalism. There a group of boys around my way, and they are drillers IRL ‚Ä¶ beefing with some boys 20 blocks away‚Ä¶ this gang warfare is not about money drug corners drug proceeds. Nothing like that it‚Äôs about rap and the Internet and bodies have dropped and talking to these boys about Africa with late stage capitalism or patriarchy. Don‚Äôt seem to be doing the job Ja is mimicking that kind of imagery.

author: @songs-of-seers5139
text: Never forget that a sitting US vice president shot a hunting buddy less than twenty years ago.  And people were definitely not much more (arguably less) outraged. Flashing a gun carried not in a holster and loaded is a problem, but so are many shooting range videos. If you're concerned about him safety, you best react more violently to someone using a scope without intent to fire and equally violently to people not minding their barrel on a range as to people flashing improperly carried guns or goofing off this way.  I love olurinatti's kindness to people being stupid thanks to cultural frames around guns, too, because it is understandable.

author: @damejanea.macdonald2371
text:
That he's getting criticism for having a gun on him in his own car with his own friends in America is not a subtle issue even before people start throwing around thug.

I *am* rolling my eyes a little at the two times in quick succession like your darling husband Mr. Sharpe, but from outside the U.S., it looks like white conservatives feel naked if they don't have at least one gun on them at all times, so it was kind of a mistake waiting to happen if you tell an American man to be careful to not show a gun on a livestream.

As a Canadian, the idea of someone having a gun in a social space like in the first one, but it's not Canada there.

author: @ToaNyroc
text: Like a lot of people have pointed out, this latest gun flashing on ig is one out of a list of incidents stretching back through the past year. So while I agree with you that a lot of racists have taken this as an opportunity to shit on black people (because when have they ever not?), defending Ja in any way is silly imo. Like I think it's one thing to push back against racists for going too far with their criticism of him, but to say that what he didn't isn't "actually wrong" because he wasn't breaking the law or hurting anyone is ignoring, willfully or not, the fact that he has been both threatening to and actively hurting people, so him waving a gun around deserves to be taken more seriously than someone who wasn't involved in all those other incidents.

author: @andykeith780
text: Loved the editing but really cannot see further than you on this argument. I don‚Äôt see how the policing of ja has anything to do with the racial profiling when it‚Äôs not anything legally unbinding that he‚Äôs doing and more breaking the civic rules of a multi billion dollar industry he‚Äôs apart of. The idea is to have preventive measures , especially when the same individual has multiple violations of civic unrest involving firearms. No it might not be illegal to have a firearm, but it‚Äôs extremely dangerous nonetheless to hold a fully loaded pistol by the fingertips smiling like it‚Äôs no big deal - and yes absolutely yes this is a huge difference than being at a gun range with safety measures and training in place. author: @Fusako8
text: This is something that has always bugged me about "American Gun Culture." There is a HUGE amount of "ok for me, but not for thee!" going on.  If you are even vaguely brownish, SOMEONE will be upset with you owning a gun. If you are a woman who isn't attracted to men and you own a gun, someone will get butthurt. If you are trans and own a gun, someone will get butthurt. Hell if you are white and NOT christian, someone will view you as a threat if you own a gun. If you are liberal/leftist/progressive and own a gun, you'll likely be attacked by both parties for owning a gun. Me, a firearms safety instructor, has been called a race traitor for teaching firearms safety to young black men. (I don't care what race/color/creed/religion someone is. I DO care that they're a responsible rational owner.)  Yeah, aside from white christianity, american gun culture is possibly the most hypocritical aspect of american culture.

author: @mopplop4525
text: Obviously waving a gun around like it‚Äôs not a deadly weapon is somewhat irresponsible but that‚Äôs it. The majority of the backlash comes from people projecting stereotypes onto him and blowing this way out of proportion. But yeah you did a great job detailing the respectability politics side of this. Great vid as always!
